tree.flow 0.1.0
  • Reference

    Tree Flow

    tree.flow.Rd

    Tree Flow is an R6 class that facilitates the creation and navigation of user-defined decision rules.

    • 'Rules' are the prescriptive decision points observed looking visually at a typical flow diagram. The class provides methods for managing rules (i.e., adding, redefining, removing)

    • Each branch of a split is structured in an environment containing the following members:

      $values

      The values beloning to the current branch: ultimately a subset of the values of "root"

      $name

      The name associated with the current branch

      $aliases

      The alternative names associated with the current branch

      $leaf.nodes

      The distinct count of values:key

      $rule

      The quote expression to be applied to $values during tree population

      $prev

      A pointer to the previous branch ($prev)

      $false

      A pointer to the child branch containing values that evaluate as FALSE when the branch rule is applied

      $true

      A pointer to the child branch containing values that evaluate as TRUE when the branch rule is applied

      $`#`

      A pointer to the class environment: this allows certain global methods to be accessed via chaining with the '$' accessor.



      Removing a branch (i.e., setting the branch to NULL) removes all child branches as well

    Public fields

    tree.name

    The name of the tree

    root

    The root of the tree

    rule.book

    The list of decision rules

    id

    The index of the current branch

    tree.key

    The data.table key column name

    graph

    The igraph-package representation of the tree

    Active bindings

    total.branches

    Count the number of branches

    depth

    Calculate tree depth

    curnt

    Returns the current branch

    parent

    Goto the parent branch: this is similar to $goto() except it only moves to the parent branch of the current branch

    leaves

    Return the content of the current branch object values

    tree

    Return the environment list for the tree

    Methods

    Public methods

    • tree.flow$new()

    • tree.flow$manage.rules()

    • tree.flow$add.branches()

    • tree.flow$set.branch()

    • tree.flow$del.branch()

    • tree.flow$goto()

    • tree.flow$list.branches()

    Method new()

    Initialize a new tree

    Usage

    tree.flow$new(init.values, init.key, name)

    Arguments

    init.values

    The values with which the tree is to be populate: must be a list (each member of the list must be the same length) or named dimensional object

    init.key

    The element or column name from init.values to serve as the data.table key to be used for counting elements in a branch

    name

    The desired name of the decision support tree

    Method manage.rules()

    Register and manage decision rules by operating on the class member $rule.book, the list of rules for use by branches. It is up to the user to ensure that the rule expression is appropriate for the data type of the values used to initialize the class (argument init.values of class method $new())

    Usage

    tree.flow$manage.rules(..., rem = FALSE, rtype = "list", .debug = FALSE)

    Arguments

    ...

    dots_list: One or more lists with members name, def, and desc

    rem

    When TRUE, the rule is removed from the class member $rule.book (see section 'Details')

    rtype

    Denotes the type of structure for the argument this.rule; list, "nlist" (nested lists), and tabular (2D objects) are supported (see section 'Details').

    .debug

    (logical) When TRUE, additional execution information is produced

    Details

    this.rule

    • name: A label for the rule

    • def: A expression operating on branch values, or a function accepting branch value as its first argument. Either option must return a logical vector when evaluated or invoked.

    • desc: The plain-language description of the rule)


    When more than one rule is supplied to '...', arguments rem and rtype, must be the same length as the number of supplied rules; otherwise, the first value in each argument is recycled to the length of '...'.

    rtype

    • list : list(name = , def = , desc = )

    • nlist : list(list(name = , def = , desc = ), list(name = , def = , desc = ), ...); a maximum depth of two is supported

    • tabular : data{table, frame}(name = c(...), def = c(...), desc = c(...))

    Returns

    The class, invisibly

    Method add.branches()

    Add empty objects to the current branch's 'true' and 'false' objects. The class object pointing to the current branch is set to the branch being modified. Do not use this method to update branch values: this method will not overwrite an existing branch. Use methods $set.branch.name() and $set.branch.rule().

    Usage

    tree.flow$add.branches(
  branch = self$curnt,
  false.label = "false",
  true.label = "true",
  final.label = "END",
  rule = quote((TRUE)),
  aliases = NULL
)

    Arguments

    branch

    The branch environment to which child branches are being added: either an object or the target branch's name.

    false.label

    The assignment object "name" in the "false" branch

    true.label

    The assignment object "name" in the "true" branch

    final.label

    The value to assign the terminating node indicator in the current branch

    rule

    A string indicating which registered rule is to be assigned to the branch before adding child

    aliases

    A character vector of additional names by which the branch may be understood (e.g., "name_2", "name_3", etc.)

    Returns

    The branch, invisibly

    Method set.branch()

    Replace the rule of the indicated branch

    Usage

    tree.flow$set.branch(
  branch = self$curnt,
  new.name = self$curnt$name,
  new.rule = self$curnt$rule
)

    Arguments

    branch

    The target branch (by name or id) or, when NULL, the current branch

    new.name

    The desired name to use for the branch

    new.rule

    The desired rule to use for the branch

    Returns

    The branch, invisibly

    Method del.branch()

    Delete a branch: child branches are consequently removed

    Usage

    tree.flow$del.branch(branch = self$curnt, confirm = TRUE)

    Arguments

    branch

    The target branch (by name or id) or, when NULL, the current branch

    confirm

    (logical | TRUE) When TRUE, deletion confirmation is provided

    Returns

    Invisibly, the class environment with the current branch set to the root

    Method goto()

    Jump to an arbitrary branch in the tree, setting the "current branch" pointer to the target branch

    Usage

    tree.flow$goto(name = NULL, id = private$envs[[name]], .verbose = FALSE)

    Arguments

    name

    The name (not alias) of the target branch

    id

    The id value of the target branch

    .verbose

    When TRUE, the current branch's ID and name are echoed

    Returns

    The current branch, invisibly

    Method list.branches()

    Print the structure of the private list of branches

    Usage

    tree.flow$list.branches()

    Returns

    The list of branches, invisibly

    Method make.decision()

    Apply a branch's rule to it's stored values and populate downstream 'true' and 'false' child branches. The branch is returned invisibly.

    Usage

    tree.flow$make.decision(branch = self$curnt, .debug = FALSE)

    Arguments

    branch

    A class branch object, defaulting to the currently pointed to branch

    .debug

    Print debugging information

    Returns

    The branch, invisibly

    Method populate()

    Iteratively populate the tree by rendering decisions only on branches that have non-NULL "true" and "false" values.

    Usage

    tree.flow$populate(branch = "root", .debug = FALSE)

    Arguments

    branch

    The target branch (by name or id) or, when NULL, "root". Iteration begins at this point in the tree.

    .debug

    Print debugging information

    Details

    For a given branch, the values that map to TRUE are copied to the current branch's corresponding member $true and vice-versa. The values of the current branch are preserved for exploration branch-by-branch.

    This is performed sequentially and recursively using a "first matching rule wins" method: this means that if the set of values for a branch could be mapped to TRUE in multiple branches of the same depth, it will only map to one branch due to the propagation of values described before.

    Population begins at the root by default. Once populated a corresponding igraph-package member $graph is created

    Returns

    The class environment, invisibly

    Method plot()

    Creates an visualization of the tree using visIgraph. The branch list is converted into a graph via graph_from_literal

    Usage

    tree.flow$plot(
  ...,
  igraph.args = NULL,
  layout.args = list(visHierarchicalLayout = list()),
  refresh = FALSE
)

    Arguments

    ...

    dots_list: igraph expressions that will customize the graph before sending to visIgraph

    igraph.args

    A named list of arguments to send to visIgraph

    layout.args

    A named list of length 1L given as list("layout name" = <argument list>) (see https://datastorm-open.github.io/visNetwork/layout.html for details

    refresh

    (logical | FALSE) When TRUE, the preceding arguments are defaulted to existing values in $private$vizArgs

    Details

    For ..., the expressions are executed in the order given.

    • Use g as the symbol for the igraph object when needed (e.g., V(g) <- ... )

    • By default, vertices are supplied with a title and level attributes; edges with title and label attributes

      • Assignment to graph objects can use <-. The graph is automatically on each pass.

      • To updated the entire graph, use the following: g <<- ...

    • Library calls should be prefixed with "igraph::" unless the library has been loaded and attached

    The class member $graph is not updated unless the self$graph <<- ... is used.

    Method clone()

    The objects of this class are cloneable with this method.

    Usage

    tree.flow$clone(deep = FALSE)

    Arguments

    deep

    Whether to make a deep clone.
